did.head: Collection Summary
did.physdesc: 92 photographic prints : black-and-white and color ; various sizes
1 optical disc (DVD-R, 11 video files) : optical, sound, color ; 4 3/4 in.

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of original visual art, manuscripts, ephemera such as posters and newsletters, photographs and artifacts such as political buttons, which documents the United Farm Workers labor movement in California during the 1970s and the Civil Rights movement in southwest Georgia during the 1960s.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Susan Due Pearcy collection was processed by Valda Morris in 2022.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Susan Due Pearcy collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Susan Due Pearcy collection (AFC 2014/028), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Susan Due Pearcy is an artist and the owner of Sugarloaf Studio in Barnesville, Maryland. Born in May 6, 1945, in St. Louis, Missouri, Susan studied art education at Southeast Missouri State University before earning a Bachelor of Science in painting, graphics and sculpture from New York University. She has worked at the Graphics Workshop and the Printmaker's Workshop in Maryland and her art has been displayed over 200 times both regionally and internationally including Russia, France and Argentina. She has been the recipient of many awards and recognitions. In 2009, she was selected as one of Maryland's Top 100 Women and is the Signature member of the Maryland Pastel Society.

In 1967, acting upon an invitation by Rev. Charles Sherrod, Susan, and her late husband Glen Pearcy, traveled to Georgia where they worked on the Southwest Georgia Project Newsletter. Glen wrote occasionally for the newsletter while Susan provided photos and sketches for the paper. In 1972, Richard Cook, a volunteer from the United Farm Workers (UFW) Union, beckoned to the couple to come to California. Susan and Glen moved from Georgia to work with the United Farm Workers at the central headquarters in La Paz, California, where Susan became the staff graphic artist for El Macriado. She designed woodblocks and linocut prints and created drawings for use on buttons, bumper strips, and in the newspaper. Susan also created the eagle that was used in the UFW's flag.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the original drawings and artwork Susan Due Pearcy created for the Southwest Georgia Project and the UFW Union including the original linocuts. It also includes a few copies of the original EL Macriado. The collection also includes some of Susan's orginal sketchbooks and artwork.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Susan Due Pearcy collection (AFC 2014/028) is organized in five series:

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

Contains newspaper clippings, handwritten and typed letters including correspondence between Susan and her sister while Susan was living in Baker County, Georgia, 1967-1968.

This series is a mixture of manuscript materials, artwork and posters. Please note that the titles for the posters were taken directly from the items themselves. In regards to the artwork the titles which appear in italics were supplied by the artist. All other titles were supplied by the archivist.
